Unnecessary Suppression
News smuggled in from the University of Maryland ha.s, both
its comic and tragic aspects. The student newspaper, The Diamond.back, printed in its Sept. 25 issue an article about the Dean of
Women receiving a traffic ticket, a picture of overcrowded
conditions, and another of the student government president
missing a meeting. Dean of Men Gary Eppley, fearing its
impression upon visiting high schoolers, seized the paper the
next day and halted its distribution. Resultant publicity reached
not only all visitors, but nearly all Baltimore as well, and papers
as far away as New York.
University officials claimed that the articles were misrepresentations, and anyway, they were in poor taste. There was some
truth in this, because the overcrowding was temporary, and the
student president arrived five minutes after the picture of his
empty chair was taken.
But none of this justifies censorship or seizure. The University of Maryland publishes enough brochures extolling the
virtues of the school. The student newspaper is supposed to be
the independent voice of the student body, and not a propaganda
tearsheet for the administration. Factual errors and part truths
should be watched by the staff, but they do not justify censorship
except in extreme and repeated cases. And silencing of honest
criticism is never justified.
The whole affair makes us- of the News-Letter realize how
fortunate we are to attend a more sensible school at Johns Hopkins.
Within the past few years, we have leveled severe editorial
criticism at the ROTC, the fraternities, the Math Department,
the Student Council, the Johns Hopkins Magazine, the football
team, the Ober Law, and Congressional investigators.
These forays have no doubt caused the school's administration
considerable embarrassment, especially in the last instance. But
only in the first ease was the editor asked to say no more. Never
within the past few years has an order on what to print or not to
print been issued, never has the paper been suppressed, and
never has an editor bitn threatened.

News smuggled in from the University of Maryland ha.s, both
its comic and tragic aspects. The student newspaper, The Diamond.back, printed in its Sept. 25 issue an article about the Dean of
Women receiving a traffic ticket, a picture of overcrowded
conditions, and another of the student government president
missing a meeting. Dean of Men Gary Eppley, fearing its
impression upon visiting high schoolers, seized the paper the
next day and halted its distribution. Resultant publicity reached
not only all visitors, but nearly all Baltimore as well, and papers
as far away as New York.
University officials claimed that the articles were misrepresentations, and anyway, they were in poor taste. There was some
truth in this, because the overcrowding was temporary, and the
student president arrived five minutes after the picture of his
empty chair was taken.
But none of this justifies censorship or seizure. The University of Maryland publishes enough brochures extolling the
virtues of the school. The student newspaper is supposed to be
the independent voice of the student body, and not a propaganda
tearsheet for the administration. Factual errors and part truths
should be watched by the staff, but they do not justify censorship
except in extreme and repeated cases. And silencing of honest
criticism is never justified.
The whole affair makes us- of the News-Letter realize how
fortunate we are to attend a more sensible school at Johns Hopkins.
Within the past few years, we have leveled severe editorial
criticism at the ROTC, the fraternities, the Math Department,
the Student Council, the Johns Hopkins Magazine, the football
team, the Ober Law, and Congressional investigators.
These forays have no doubt caused the school's administration
considerable embarrassment, especially in the last instance. But
only in the first ease was the editor asked to say no more. Never
within the past few years has an order on what to print or not to
print been issued, never has the paper been suppressed, and
never has an editor bitn threatened.
